body:
+1

It looks good overall and all unit test cases finished successfully.
Push it. :)
The patch looks nice to me. I leave some trivial comments.

Thanks guys for the review. Iâ€™ll commit it shortly.
If you have more review, please let me know

Hi @hyunsik 

Thanks for your contribution and simple codes by ServiceTracker looks very pretty to me.
But unfortunately, I couldn't run Tajo HA cluster with a shell script (start-tajo.sh) on my macbook as follows:

2015-01-23 11:15:46,876 INFO org.apache.tajo.master.rm.TajoWorkerResourceManager: Released QueryMaster (q_1421979321683_0001) resource.
2015-01-23 11:15:46,885 INFO org.apache.tajo.util.history.HistoryWriter: Create query history file: hdfs://localhost:9010/tmp/tajo-blrunner/staging/history/20150123/query-list/query-list-111546.hist
2015-01-23 11:15:57,739 INFO org.apache.tajo.session.SessionManager: Session f103d278-ab81-47f4-a19b-3e9f561d73fd is removed.
2015-01-23 11:16:09,009 ERROR org.apache.tajo.master.TajoMaster: RECEIVED SIGNAL 15: SIGTERM
2015-01-23 11:16:09,010 INFO org.apache.tajo.master.TajoMaster: ============================================
2015-01-23 11:16:09,010 INFO org.apache.tajo.master.TajoMaster: TajoMaster received SIGINT Signal

2015-01-23 11:16:09,022 INFO org.apache.tajo.util.history.HistoryWriter: HistoryWriter_127.0.0.1_26001 stopped.
2015-01-23 11:16:09,022 INFO org.apache.tajo.util.history.HistoryCleaner: History cleaner stopped
2015-01-23 11:16:09,023 INFO org.apache.tajo.rpc.NettyServerBase: Rpc (QueryCoordinatorProtocol) listened on 127.0.0.1:26001) shutdown
2015-01-23 11:16:09,025 INFO org.apache.tajo.rpc.NettyServerBase: Rpc (TajoMasterClientProtocol) listened on 127.0.0.1:26002) shutdown
2015-01-23 11:16:09,026 INFO org.apache.hadoop.yarn.util.AbstractLivelinessMonitor: SessionLivelinessMonitor thread interrupted
2015-01-23 11:16:09,026 ERROR org.apache.tajo.master.rm.TajoWorkerResourceManager: java.lang.InterruptedException
2015-01-23 11:16:09,027 INFO org.apache.tajo.rpc.NettyServerBase: Rpc (TajoResourceTrackerProtocol) listened on 127.0.0.1:26003) shutdown
2015-01-23 11:16:09,027 INFO org.apache.hadoop.yarn.util.AbstractLivelinessMonitor: WorkerLivelinessMonitor thread interrupted
2015-01-23 11:16:09,028 INFO org.apache.tajo.master.TajoMaster: Tajo Master main thread exiting
2015-01-23 11:16:09,117 INFO org.apache.tajo.master.TajoMaster: SHUTDOWN_MSG:
/************************************************************
SHUTDOWN_MSG: Shutting down TajoMaster at jaehwaui-mbp.server.gruter.com/192.168.0.245
************************************************************/

For reference, I could run Tajo HA cluster with Tajo command as follows:
$TAJO_HOME/bin/tajo master

Cheers
Jaehwa
For reference, after finding your comment, I'll check the patch such as JDBC, HA on YARN, auto-failover.

I've add two configuration following:

```
tajo.history.query.replication
tajo.history.task.replication
```

Please review again
Thanks

Hi @hyunsik 

I added the exception handling code. If possible, could you check the pathch again?
Sure, I'll review it soon.
Thank you for your testing. I'll dig into the problem :)

@blrunner TajoMaster seems to be shutdown according to your log.

Could you point out any abnormal line in the log? I could find only SIGTERM signal. It seems to be triggered from external something.

Sorry @hyunsik .

I found that SIGTERM signal had happened by wrong configuration. 
I'm testing the patch with various environment.
I'll give feedback as soon as possible. :)
I just fixed TajoWorkerClientService::getQueryHistory bug and triggered TravisCI.

Hi @hyunsik 

The patch ran as expected on my testing cluster and all unit test cases finished successfully.
But Travis CI build failed as follows:

{code:xml}
Running org.apache.tajo.ha.TestHAServiceHDFSImpl
Formatting using clusterid: testClusterID

In addition, I added ignoring {{T_SCHEDULE}} event in {{Task}}


+1

It looks good to me and all unit cases finished successfully.
Push it. :)

+1

It looks good to me and all unit test cases finished successfully.
Push it~ :)

+1 LGTM
Ship it!

Hi @blrunner ,

That is a part of original unit tests; i.e.g, TestHAServiceHDFSImpl::testAutoFailOver. The failure is not related to this unit test because the following unit tests are passed well until the failure point. 

```
Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 18.096 sec - in org.apache.tajo.ha.TestHAServiceHDFSImpl
```

According to logs, the failure seems to be caused by HDFS mini cluster, which occurs occasionally. Anyway, I trigger the TravisCI.

+1

I think that the error cause was TAJO-1318.
Shit it. :)

Hi @blrunner, your patch looks good.
I left some minor comments.
Please consider them.

Thanks for your comment.
Those changes look good to me.
+1!
It should be separated compilation and test phase on maven build, because parallel compilation is not supported by maven.

This build failure already reported to MNG jira. It needs to find a workaround for this build issue. More details can be found in below link.
https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MNG-5750

+1

It looks good to me. 
Ship it. :)

+1

Thank you for your contribution.
You resolved our endemic test problems and all unit test cases finished successfully.

Push it. :)

+1
Looks good to me. Thank you for your contribution!

@jinossy thanks for your review.
I fixed it.

+1 LGTM!
I've verify on cluster.
Just committed. And also verified on my ubuntu box.

+1 LGTM.
Ship it!

Iâ€™ve decrease the travis parallel forks to 2. because jvm terminated

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-surefire-plugin:2.17:test (default-test) on project tajo-core: ExecutionException: java.lang.RuntimeException: The forked VM terminated without properly saying goodbye. VM crash or System.exit called?
```

The latest travis failure is network issue

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal on project tajo-catalog-server: Could not resolve dependencies for project org.apache.tajo:tajo-catalog-server:jar:0.10.0-SNAPSHOT: Could not transfer artifact org.apache.derby:derby:jar:10.8.2.2 from/to central (http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2): GET request of: org/apache/derby/derby/10.8.2.2/derby-10.8.2.2.jar from central failed: Connection reset -> [Help 1]
```
+1 LGTM!

Hi @sirpkt, 
Could you trigger this unit test?
@blrunner Could you trigger TravisCI?

+1 ship it!

The patch includes the correct bug fix and enough unit tests.
@sirpkt Could you please commit this patch to both branch-0.10.0 and master branch?

+1 LGTM.
Please add some explanations before you commit.

Thank you for the comments, @hyunsik, @jinossy 
I just committed to master and branch-0.10.0.
Thanks for quick review. :)

@hyunsik 

Sure, I've just triggered it. :)
+1 ship it!
Could you please commit it to both 0.10.0 branch and master branch?
Sure. cherry-pick into branch-0.10.0.

+1 ship it. Thanks.

It should be committed to only master branch.
You should add tajo-cli-module in tajo-dist maven plugin
+1 ship it. The patch looks good to me.
@sirpkt Could you add this patch to both master and 0.10.0 branch?
@jinossy Thanks! I missed it. I'll add it.

Thank you for the review, @hyunsik 
I just committed the patch to both master and 0.10.0 branch.
@jinossy I just updated the tajo-dist/pom.xml.

+1 LGTM
I'll fix the Unit test failure
Could you update the tajo-cli module ?

@ykrips 
I can't run the query. If you ready to review, please let me know.

Query : select l_orderkey, l_partkey from lineitem order by l_suppkey;

+1

It looks good to me and all unit test cases finished successfully.
Ship it. :)

@jinossy
Thank you for posting trace info. Finding a root cause of this issue will start right now.
This patch is not yet ready for review
This patch should rebase against the latest revision. I'll update the patch soon.

@jinossy,
I did not find any issues on my ubuntu box, but this issue may be related to my recent commit. This commit will be reverted.

My testing cluster is 1Master + 4Worker. Did you test on cluster ?
I also investigate the problems.

Thanks
Well, I don't have any testing cluster for Tajo or hadoop, so keep finding suitable servers for test.

Hi @ykrips, thanks for your work.
In overall, the patch looks good to me.
Only one thing I want to suggest is the table name.
Since the newly added table contains the information of query masters as well as workers, I think that `cluster` is the more proper name than `workers`.
What do you think about it?
My recent work for IdleStateHandler cause this issue. I will find out another way to clear un-used resource on netty servers and clients.
Good idea. `cluster` would be better. fix up and post the commit soon.

Hello All,
I have been working on the optimization work for network codes, and still working on. If I finished an optimization work for netty codes, I will leave a comment on this request.
Thank you for your work.
I fixed the test failure.

@sirpkt, thanks for your nice work.
The basic approach looks good to me.
I left some comments.

Sometimes, outer joins can be associative under some conditions. (Please refer to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20022196/are-left-outer-joins-associative, https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/LanguageManual+Joins)
So, we should handle them, but I think that it should be done in another issue.

Hi @jinossy 

Thanks for your works.
But I found a build failure as follows:

## {code:xml}

Hello All,
It has been a long time to enable a netty4 library to tajo project. Finally, performance on netty4 was achieved to the acceptable level, and errors on Travis CI build was resolved. Now, I think, it is a time to discuss on any missing points or any potential issues.

@ykrips, thanks for your great work!
I have one question, just from my curiosity. How did you evaluate the performance with Netty4?

Hello @jihoonson ,
I have done with several items. First, disabled nagle algorithm as possible. Enabling nagle algorithm will reduce the resource use on network infrastructure, but it will delay network transmission. Also, netty4 team recommend not to use flush() function frequently, but it also delays the network transmission. Second, I have set the send and receive buffer size of servers and clients as possible. Low buffer size also delays the network performance, and providers and consumers wait until the buffer is empty. Finally, I have merged and refactored the source code to use shared eventloopgroup. Creating a object which tightly coupled to the operating system resource is expensive operation, and when creating these objects frequently, it may lead starvation on native memory and network resources.

The patch contains a workaround code which can fix the bug right now.

I have some comments. Your workaround code seems to try to firstly find the order of joins whose join types is same. In my opinion, this approach may miss some of join order combinations. It may cause sub-optimal join orders in some cases. I think that the right way is to improve the findBestPair() to find only associative join orders. It would be great if we do it in another jira.
